Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Analysis of McCall Glacier ice core and related modern process studies
Award.AbstractNarration: This is a collaborative project involving four institutions. The proposed research addresses two major questions related to climate in the eastern Alaskan Arctic: 1) How has climate, terrestrial ecology, and pollutant transport changed over the past 250 years in this region, based on ice core reconstructions from McCall Glacier? and 2) How well can we overcome the challenges of core proxy interpretations from ice cores taken from small polythermal valley glaciers through modern-process studies? To answer these questions the investigators conduct an inter-disciplinary analysis of ice core proxies, atmospheric dynamics, modern processes, and numerical ice flow modeling. A 152-meter long core has already been drilled through McCall Glacier and analyzed for 35 chemical proxies. The proposed work will focus on 1) interpretation of these proxies, 2) analysis of pollen in the core, 3) process studies to identify sources of pollen to McCall Glacier, 4) tying the weather and climate record of the past 50 years to the upper section of the core, 5) continuing 3D flow modeling of the glacier and local weather observations, 6) conducting modern process investigations of the effects of seasonal melt on the generation of the core proxy record. The project will support two graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ice cores from glaciers and ice sheets provide a wealth of information useful for reconstructing past climates. These paleo-climate reconstructions are critical for allowing climate scientists to understand the natural variability in the Earth’s climate and to identify anthropogenic changes in the Earth’s climate.

One of the most common ways ice core data has been used to reconstruct past climates is through temperature reconstructions based on oxygen isotopes contained in ice cores. Our work on this project focused on developing methods to determine large-scale weather patterns, such as the location of high and low pressure centers, based on the chemical constituents contained in an ice core collected from McCall Glacier in the Brooks Range of Alaska. The methods we have developed will provide climate scientists with the ability to understand how weather patterns have changed over the period of time represented by an ice core. This weather pattern information then allows climate scientists to identify cool or warm, wet or dry, cloudy or clear, and surface and upper level wind directions for each year represented in the ice core. For the McCall Glacier we will be able to apply the methods developed as part of this project to reconstruct weather patterns for the past 250 years. Of the 27 different chemical constituents identified in the McCall ice core the vast majority allowed us to reconstruct robust weather patterns. By using several different ice core constituents for our weather pattern reconstruction we are able to provide greater detail regarding past weather than is possible using just a single constituent.

An important part of all scientific research is communicating your findings to other scientists, and we have done this this by attending scientific meetings and conferences and publishing our results in peer reviewed scientific journals. As part of our work on this project we used an artificial neural network data analysis technique, known as self-organizing maps (SOMs), to identify large-scale weather patterns and relate those to the chemical record contained in the ice core. The use of SOMs for this type of research is still relatively new and we have published a paper that describes our new technique. The development of new techniques, such as this, is useful to other scientists as it broadens the set of tools we have available to study climate.

While our work on this project focused on the weather patterns in the vicinity of Alaska, based on data from the McCall Glacier ice core, the methods we have developed are likely to be applicable to ice cores from other middle and high latitude locations.
